utterances: Just as the president was heading off to Mar-a-Lago for the Thanksgiving weekend, his company, The Trump Organization, announced it was severing ties with one of its New York properties.
The Trump SoHo Hotel had been plagued for several months by bad press and low occupancy rates.
Its premier restaurant on the ground floor closed.
Not far from the hotel in SoHo, another Trump building is also struggling.
TIM O'BRIEN: Recently, there's been a drop-off in the resale prices of Trump Tower condos.

Thats Tim O'Brien, the executive editor of Bloomberg View and the author of ""TrumpNation: The Art Of Being The Donald."" He says what's interesting is that real estate, generally, is doing well in New York City.
So it's unclear why the prices in Trump Tower have dropped so significantly.

O'BRIEN: Some people have attributed it to the fact that people don't want to be in the same building with the Trumps now for a variety of reasons, not necessarily even a political - it's just a pain in the neck to be in a building that the Secret Service and the New York Police Department are routinely locking down.
Revenues from Trump's golf courses near Los Angeles and the Bronx have dropped.
His two courses in Scotland lost close to $25 million in 2016.
Many charities have pulled lucrative events from some of his hotels.
The Trump Organization is also having trouble launching a new line of four-star star hotels called Scion.
Philip Kingston, a Democratic representative of the Dallas City Council, says plans to put a Scion in his city met a lot of opposition.
He recalls his first reaction to the news.
Strongly negative.
Why is that?
As part of our series Musicians At Work, I spent some time with a successful background singer with solo aspirations of her own.
Tiffany Riddick is currently on tour as one of three women supporting R&B superstar Beyonce.
(Soundbite of song, ""Dangerously In Love"")
(Singing) Baby, I'm so proud, so proud to be your girl.
You make this confusion go on away from this cold and mixed-up world.
Unidentified Woman #1 (Background Singer): (Singing) I'm in love with you.
You set me free.
(Singing) I can't do this thing called life without you here with me.
Dangerously in love.
In love.
Last week, I went backstage to meet Tiffany Riddick before a Beyonce show at Washington's Verizon Center.
She said she came very close to missing out on working with Beyonce altogether.
Someone called me who knew auditions that were going on and said, I think you'd be a good fit.
I told her about you.
You should go.
But I received the message probably two day - no, a day or two later.
I was terrible with my voicemail.
So by the time I heard about the opportunity, they had already filled the position.
But the creative director, she did give me the opportunity to audition nonetheless and said, I'll keep you in mind.
And like with many things, you sort of put it in the back of your head like I'll never get called back.
She was just trying to be polite.
And I remember she wrote my phone number down on a piece of, like, bubble gum paper.
A bubble gum wrapper?
A little bubble gum wrapper, something really small.
So I pretty much left there feeling, okay, it was a great opportunity to say, I auditioned for Beyonce, but I didn't really expect anything.
And two years later - almost - she called me back.
Luckily, I had the same phone number.
And I was fortunate enough to not have to audition just because I already met with her earlier.
So you've worked with the likes of not only Beyonce Knowles but Mariah Carey…
Yes.
…Christina Aguilera.
Yes.
Do you have to have the right fit with the star?
How does that work?
Absolutely.
In addition to probably a personality match and just being able to - for instance, an artist like Beyonce who's a very, very hard worker.
And if you're not conditioned to work as hard, if not harder, then it probably wouldn't be the best fit for you.
But other than characteristic or personality traits, it's also musical aspects in terms of tone, texture of your voice.
For instance, if it's a song that's more of a ballad or a quiet or a softer texture, you need to be flexible enough to adapt.
How do you balance your role as a background vocalist with still trying to give your best performance and not upstage Beyonce?
Right.

Well, the wonderful thing that I love, particularly about Beyonce, is that while she's a very successful artist, she's not at all intimidated by the success of other artists or the talents that they have.
We do have several portions in the show where she allows us to show some of our musical talents.
But then also, I guess it's just a matter of knowing the role that you play.
I'm also an artist myself.
I'm also a gospel recording artist.
But I know that at the moment, that's not what my position is.
So it's sort of an investment, you know?
You sort of step back and then I truly believe that great things could come from it.
You say she gives you a moment to showcase your stuff.
What is it that you get to do during that moment when the spotlight is on you?
Well, actually, it's during the segue from her song - actually, one of Destiny's Child's songs, ""Say My Name,"" transitioning into ""Jumpin' Jumpin'"".

And we sort of do a, I guess you could call it a gospel-influenced version of ""Jumpin' Jumpin'."" And during that time, she introduces us to the crowd and then she actually steps to the side and just allows us to sort of take it away.
Well, it's great.
It's fun, really fun.
Can I ask you to give me a little sample?
Okay.
(Singing) Ladies, leave your men at home.
The club is full of ballers and their pockets full grown.
And all you fellas leave your girl with her friends.
'Cause it's 11:30 and the club is jumpin'.
Lovely.
Thank you.
How many of you are there?
Three.
Three backgrounds.
Three background vocalists.
Yeah.
Do you three form a bond?
Oh, wow.
We're like sisters.
And we get along like sisters.
We fight like sisters.
We love, you know, each other like sisters.
So we have a wonderful bond.
What do you wear?
Oh, wow.
We actually have dresses similar to - I guess you could say they're adapted from the ""Dreamgirls"" movie that Beyonce was a star in.
So we're dressed in '60s style - sequins, dresses, all black, and bob wigs - very '60s era.
Do you all do any little dancing?
Oh, yes.
Yes.
We actually told Beyonce that after this was over, we were going to have a diet called The Beyonce Experience Diet.
Because we move so much on stage that, oh, collectively, we've probably all lost about 80, 90 pounds since the beginning of the tour, just because we're so active on the stage.
Maybe you need to show me if you could do.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I could.
I really, really had a good time.
I read in your bio material that you sort of struggled at some point with whether this was the right path to take.
Yes.
Yes.
A regular record executive that will remain unnamed actually told me that while I had the vocal ability, I didn't possess the particular look of a recording artist, whatever that is.
And that he didn't think that I would be able to compare with the artists on his roster.
And that was definitely a blow.
That was definitely a blow.
And it caused me to reevaluate.
It did cause some doubt, initially, you know, just say, okay, is he really right?
And do I have it?
And then later on, I realized that that was his flaw, not mine.
But it helped me build character as well.
And it gave me more of a reason to want to pursue.

While my particular - my personal goals not be - may not be completely and totally aligned with this particular opportunity, this opportunity has showed me how I can be successful in my own career and sort of surpass, maybe, what some others might have said.
It has been fun talking to you.
You as well.
